ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course taught me the basics of what it is like to actually do science. Learning how to do science safely is also something that I'd like to emphasize. I also improved my scientific writing and organizational skills.
Basic organic chemistry techniques for synthesizing and purifying organic compounds, including vacuum filtration, recrystallization, reflux, TLC, IR spec analysis, and melting point analysis.

This class taught me a lot about various organic synthesis techniques and how to operate safely and properly in a laboratory. It also taught me about proper laboratory protocol and how to effectively document and prepare for lab.
Taking this course allowed me to learn many experimental skills, including how to perform recrystallization, distillation, reflux, infrared spectroscopy, and column and thin layer chromatography.

I learned how to work safely in a chemistry lab and apply knowledge from both lab and other reading materials to perform various procedures including purification, synthesis, and distillation. I also learned how to operate safely by producing chemical lab tables sourced from SDS sheets to ensure proper safety. A step above general chemistry, I learned how to act independently and solve problems in chemistry.
I developed organic lab safety skills and chemical lab techniques.

This was my first in person laboratory course at Yale. I learned a lot about lab safety, the proper techniques to use in an organic chemistry lab, and the different methods used for purifying and assess the purification of a product
Many chemical analysis techniques such as TLC, IR, etc. Performing experimental techniques. Being familiar in a lab environment
Lab Skills, organic chemistry
I developed lab skills and practical ochem.
Introductory organic chemistry lab techniques, such as extraction, recrystallization, chromatography, and synthesis. Practiced scientific writing.
Very helpful basic laboratory techniques as well as synthesis labs.

In this course, I learned many experimental techniques and applications of organic chemistry concepts. Some techniques I learned included distillation, chromatography, spectroscopy, and melting point analysis.
Throughly learned a set of lab techniques in this course - many were repeated every week which helped with reinforcing the learning.

This was my first lab course since I had placed directly into Organic Chemistry. I learned how to conduct basic organic lab principles such as extraction, reflux, distillation, chromatography, and synthesis. I also learned how to collect data via IR, MP instruments, and TLC. I learned how to write an experimental plan which gave me some background into scientific writing.
I learned organic chemistry techniques.
I learned and reinforced strong laboratory technique in Organic Chemistry. I learned to appreciate the variety of techniques introduced in the lab and how to build a lab procedure.
Lab etiquette and organic chemistry in a more hand-on way.
Learned how to synthesize materials and do a reflux reaction. Also learned how to properly dispose of chemicals and clean glassware.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The weakness of the course is that if you have not taken a lab class here before then it can be offputting as an fgli student to have to spend additional money to buy a lab coat and the student lab notebook for the course. Additionally, how can the department justify the course being half a credit? The workload was definitely higher than for most of my 1 credit classes.

Strengths: fun, engaging labs that almost never took the whole class period; collaborative, relaxed environment; doable quizzes that students had an opportunity to retake to show mastery of the material; efficient lab write-ups; and Professor DiMeglio's pre-lab videos, which were really helpful in terms of knowing what to do in the lab. Weaknesses: huge variation in grading based on TAs and unclear expectations for post lab assignment A especially, which led to point deductions on formatting issues that hadn't been explicitly covered in any lab documents. Also, EPs took awhile and felt like busy work.

The course was very helpful in learning various lab techniques. I learnt a lot and got to take command of my own lab practices. Sometimes, though, it felt a little disorganized and I was not exactly sure what was happening in the course.

I think this is an excellent course; it is formatted well to allow students to learn without stress. Between the EPs, the post-lab quizzes, and the post-lab reports, students have ample opportunity to get familiar with the experiments that they perform, as well as the concepts that underlie these experiments. I particularly liked that students have two opportunities to take the quizzes, so that they have a chance to improve. My only suggestion would be to have the quizzes open for between 10 minutes and 30 minutes, to allow people to actually think about the questions and answer carefully, rather than being stressed by a five minute timer.

This course is very well designed and prepares students for success.
Weaknesses arise when the course does not align with the lecture course, so materials must be learned either ahead or behind. However, overall this course has few weaknesses. However, lack of reading the prelab materials etc resulted in some mismatches in directions regarding both lab procedure and graded assignments (rubric on canvas vs TA preference)
The strengths are the quiz second chances.

Strengths: no pre-lab quizzes, the ability to retake all the quizzes on Fridays, the (optional) pre-lab lectures made it much easier to do the lab and were super helpful. the course was well organized.

Weaknesses: some of the staff made it not the most comfortable environment. I could hear them talking about students in the room next door. There was also some inconsistency among the instructors about what was appropriate to do in the lab -- there were several times when I would do something after getting advice from one instructor on how to do it and then another instructor would come around and lecture me on why I was doing it wrong. Teresa was sometimes rude. 

Why are Yale lab courses still half a credit? 

I honestly think this course would not have been bad at all if I didn't have negative experiences with a few of the instructors. I think that a lot of people probably had a good experience in the lab and would guess that most people's assessment of this course will be good.
It was a very strong course, i learned more than in most of my courses at yale and was great practice for organic chemistry lecture, only thing i would improve is covid accommodations
It was well organized

Strengths: The readings were clear and not too long. As an off-sequence course, there were many opportunities to direct questions directly to instructors. Both Aaron and Christine were around during lab and gave instructive feedback.
Weaknesses: Course material can be more organized. It is evident that much material is reused from previous semesters, and sometimes the lab numbers don't match (e.g., it would read "Lab 7" in an assignment, but it's actually referring to Lab 4). Many assignments were posted on Canvas but not dated, so students have to pay special attention to the deadlines.

There is amazing support from TAs, Aaron Clark, and the entire Organic Chemistry lab community. There are also clear expectations and plenty of opportunities to get clarification. I felt that the course syllabus could be improved so that there is more transparency regarding deadlines, as there were moments of uncertainty regarding exactly what was due during the semester. More communication between the TAs and the course coordinators could help relieve some stress regarding deadlines and expectations.
Not super heavy on grades, and it was fun to do.

The type of assignments and the assignment frequencies were excellent. We had to write a pre-lab summary called an EP (experimental plan). These were very helpful and it was great only to have two post-lab assignments the whole semester. Also had bi-weekly quizzes which we had two tries on -- the two tries were vital towards me actually being able to understand and work through the material. This course truly felt like a half-credit course, unlike many lab courses which are so frustrating because of the huge workload. Good course overall, plus I learned a lot about lab techniques and working in the chemistry lab.
strengths: well organized, straight forward, and support when asked. I did feel like the sections differed vary differently based on the TA. I wish there was more of a consensus on grading.
This course is very good at teaching students organic chemistry without stressing them out.
This course was very disorganized. Due dates were not posted on Canvas, things were not communicated in a timely manner, and expectations were confusing.

I think the strengths of the course were how each lab was introduced and conducted. It seemed like each lab had a specific focus that built upon the last one. One weakness of the course was that one of the labs seemed out of order. It utilized a technique taught later in the course, perhaps it could be re-ordered to fit better.

This lab is much better than gen chem labs. You only have to do two lab reports and you get to retake each quiz. You also do not need to watch every single lab video (they can be more than an hour long). Just read through the manual and find parts you don't understand in the video. A weakness is that they are very strict when grading EPs. They will take off points for formatting and other things that don't have anything to do with your understanding of the content.

Strengths: the overall structure of the class and the way that the lab readings aided in doing the work 

Weaknesses: we were kinda guinea pigs at some points during the class so that was an interesting experience which was not the most fun thing in the world.

The first lab was super hard! We were not ready for that and it should have stayed as the fifth lab like in the previous semester. Also, the questions at the end were unnecessary since we couldn't answer them due to not learning the material yet.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would explain this to somebody who has a genuine interest in chemistry. I can also see the course being extremely helpful for students looking to get into research over the summer or the following school year. You do really gain at least some understanding of how things work and confidence working at the lab.
Yesin all likelihood you have to take this if you're premed or a chem major, but it's a good lab that can actually be quite fun!

Yes! It is a great way to fulfill a lab requirement and taught me a lot about how organic synthesis operates. It is a warm environment that fosters learning, rather than perfectionism which was great for me as this was my first lab course.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students  it's a great way to get familiar with chemical experiments in a supportive and encouraging environment! If you're taking it for a major or a pre-professional track, then you can rest assured that this required course will be worth your while, too. You'll learn a lot, and it's easy to succeed as long as you do the work and incorporate professor/TA feedback.

I would absolutely recommend this course. It is likely a requirement for a major/pre-med but I thought it was both reasonable and very fun. I felt so much more confident in the lab after taking the course.
Yes because it is probably the only lab offered here at Yale that is truly a half credit.
Absolutely, not only good lab class but also great to go with organic chemistry
If they need it for a requirement yes but dont take this class for fun as you do have to put a lot of time and work into it.
You're probably required to take orgo anyways, and I wouldn't advise against the off-sequence one. If you're just interested in it, sure, it's not nearly as hard as gen-chem lab.

Would highly recommend if you enjoy chemistry and/or labs
(to be fair, it's probably a requirement if you're taking the class, but I still enjoyed it)
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students who are interested in organic chemistry and eager to understand how they can better understand these concepts in an experimental lens.
Yes, pairs nicely with orgo lecture if you take lecture on-sequence.

I would! This has been the best lab course I have taken at Yale thus far, in large part because it actually feels like a half-credit course -- and you learn a lot in an engaging way too. My TA was great. Aaron and Prof. DiMeglio are friendly and willing to help.
Unless if you have to, I wouldn't take this class for credit since it is 0.5 credits but the work of 1 credit, but for any STEM major/student taking Orgo 1, this is a solid class/lab.
Yes! It was a fun lab and more chill than general chemistry.

If you are going to take the lab, both Dr. Clark and Dr. DiMeglio are great professors! As a chemistry lab, this course was much better run than the general chemistry labs. That said, the workload and time commitment are closer to 0.75 or 1 credit(s).
If you have to take it.
For all the premed students, I mean yes I would recommend. For students who are not premed and want to take this course, I think it is a course that is worth taking as it is very engaging and fun.
No.

extras.title: CHEM 222L 01 - Lab for Organic Chemistry I
